stem: A 54-year-old client with a confirmed large pulmonary embolism (PE) is hypotensive and unresponsive. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: At 07:00, the client is experiencing a progression to massive (obstructive) PE, evidenced by acute hypotension and hypoxemia.
Background: The client has a history of DVT that transitioned to PE. Initial treatment included Heparin. The client has a history of a major GI bleed two years ago.
Assessment: Current vital signs include BP 72/40 mmHg, HR 142 bpm, RR 36 breaths/min, and SpO2 78% on 15L NRM. The client is cyanotic around the mouth and unresponsive to verbal stimuli.
Recommendation: Given the client's critical condition, I recommend initiating rescue thrombolytic therapy with Alteplase (t-PA) immediately. Prepare for potential complications, including bleeding. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and neurological status is essential.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 72/40, HR 142, RR 36, SpO2 78% on 15L NRM.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: CT scan confirms large saddle pulmonary embolism obstructing blood flow to both lungs.

conditionOptions.text: Massive Pulmonary Embolism with Obstructive Shock

actionOptions.text: Administer Alteplase (t-PA) IV infusion as prescribed.
Avoid all invasive procedures once infusion starts.
Elevate the legs above the level of the heart.

parameterOptions.text: Level of consciousness and pupil response.

rationale.correct: The client's hypotension (BP 72/40) and hypoxia (SpO2 78%) indicate obstructive shock due to a Massive PE (c2). Alteplase (t-PA) (a1) is the appropriate intervention for hemodynamically unstable PE to dissolve the clot and restore pulmonary blood flow. Due to the increased bleeding risk associated with thrombolytics, all new invasive procedures should be avoided (a2) after the infusion starts. Close monitoring for signs of intracranial hemorrhage, such as changes in the level of consciousness and pupil response (p1), is crucial. Continuous assessment of blood pressure and MAP (p2) is necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment and detect any further hemodynamic instability.
clinicalPearls: Thrombolytics dissolve existing clots, while anticoagulants prevent the formation of new clots.
Massive PE is defined as a systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg or a drop > 40 mmHg from baseline for > 15 minutes.
Pulse oximetry can be unreliable in shock states; arterial blood gases provide a more accurate assessment of oxygenation and ventilation.

questionTrap.trap: Performing invasive procedures such as drawing arterial blood gases or inserting a Foley catheter after the administration of t-PA increases the risk of bleeding complications.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Ensure all necessary invasive procedures are completed before initiating thrombolytic therapy to minimize the risk of bleeding.

mnemonic.title: t-PA Trip
mnemonic.expansion: T-Target the clot. P-Prevent punctures. A-Assess Neuro status.
